meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits the <radical>greenhouse</radical>, destroying the last remaining plant life in the area. The tsunami recedes, and there is nothing but sand, and the lands become a <kanji>desert</kanji>.

Next to the <radical>scooter</radical>, there's a <radical>flag</radical> warning you that there are <radical>sheep</radical> around here, so you should go <kanji>slow</kanji>. That means you might be <kanji>late</kanji>, but at least the sheep will be okay!

There is a <radical>circumference</radical> around someone's <radical>hair</radical>, as in, you can see a circle drawn around the top of their head. As you examine it closer, and pull at it a bit, you realize that someone has <kanji>carve</kanji>d the hair off someone's head!
A <radical>tsunami</radical> will pick up a bunch of <radical>shellfish</radical> and dump them on your shore, so you take a <radical>knife</radical> and <kanji>measure</kanji> them.
If you scrape a sharp <radical>stone</radical> against your <radical>skin</radical>, it will <kanji>tear</kanji>. The sharp stone tears your skin. It hurts!
The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <kanji>cottage</kanji>.
Try to <radical>say</radical> something to a <radical>lifeguard</radical> and you'll just end up getting a <kanji>lecture</kanji>.

A <radical>tsunami</radical>, once stopped by a <radical>belt</radical>, will begin to <kanji>stagnate</kanji>. This belt is a belt of water resistance, so the belt stops the tsunami. The belt has caused the tsunami to stagnate.
You create a <radical>thread</radical> with someone by <radical>call</radical>ing out to them to <kanji>introduce</kanji> yourself.
The <radical>jammed in</radical> radical and the <kanji>jammed in</kanji> kanji are the same!

The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>oneself</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>oneself</kanji> as well.

If you're on the edge of a <radical>cliff</radical> with a <radical>snake</radical>, that's a <kanji>misfortune</kanji>. You're hanging off the edge of this cliff and you can't pull yourself back up. Then you notice a snake approaching your fingers, looking like it's gonna bite you. What a misfortune!
The <radical>turtle</radical> radical and the <kanji>turtle</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Nice!

The <radical>ground</radical> and a <radical>shuriken</radical> have <kanji>mutual</kanji> respect for one another. The shuriken respects the ground because of how solid and stable it is, and the ground respects the shuriken for how pointy it is. They have great mutual respect here.

Tie a <radical>squid</radical> to a <radical>knife</radical> and you get a <kanji>sword</kanji>! Knives are too small to be considered a sword on their own. That's why you strapped a squid to it. They're the right shape, kinda pointed, so no one will know it's just a knife.

In <radical>spring</radical>, your <radical>measurement</radical>s will reveal your <kanji>lifespan</kanji>. Only in spring can you measure your lifespan, just as easily as you measure your height and weight.

Your <radical>ear</radical> listens to your <radical>heart</radical> and feels <kanji>shame</kanji>. Your heart is full of shame for how you’ve lived your life and when your ear hears all the things you’ve done, your ear feels shame too.

There’s a <radical>tree</radical> in your <radical>hair</radical>, I think it’s a <kanji>cedar</kanji>. How did that cedar tree get in your hair?

(Certain types of cedar trees have bark that comes off in fine threads, making them very hairy trees. So this kanji makes perfect sense!)
A <radical>tsunami</radical> carries a <radical>cross</radical> into your <kanji>soup</kanji>. Hey tsunami, I was eating that soup!

Your <radical>mouth</radical> is wearing a <radical>mask</radical> so people won't realize you're the one being so <kanji>boisterous</kanji> as you eat your <kanji>miso</kanji>. If you cover your mouth with this mask, no one will know you're such a boisterous eater of miso.
<radical>Fire</radical>, <radical>fire</radical>, <kanji>flame</kanji>! There’s flames everywhere!
The <radical>sake</radical> radical and the <kanji>sake</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Sweet.
The <radical>ability</radical> to <radical>boil</radical> is one of the main abilities of a <kanji>bear</kanji>.

You have an <radical>animal</radical> and you <radical>say</radical> it’s a <radical>dog</radical> to prevent it from going to <kanji>prison</kanji>. Dogs are the only animals that don’t have to go to prison. Your animal is not a dog, but you say it is to prevent it from going to prison.

You have an <radical>alcohol</radical> <radical>nine</radical> times stronger than any other drink, in a bottle shaped like a <radical>cross</radical>, and you drink it all and become <kanji>drunk</kanji>. You're like, so drunk right now from all that alcohol. Nine times more drunk than ever before.
To make <radical>alcohol</radical> the <radical>key</radical> is to ferment it. But, if you ferment it a certain way, it will become <kanji>vinegar</kanji>.

You toss a pair of <radical>gold</radical> <radical>mustache</radical>s into your <kanji>cooking pot</kanji> and begin simmering them. Some people use bay leaves and whatnot, but where you're from, there's no seasoning you'd rather have in your cooking pot than a couple of gold mustaches.
The <radical>tsunami</radical>s during the <radical>old</radical> <radical>moon</radical>s (many moons ago) were responsible for the world's <kanji>lake</kanji>s.
<radical>Gold</radical> is not the <radical>same</radical> as <kanji>copper</kanji>. They are two different metals. Gold is not the same as copper.

This <radical>tsunami</radical> is the <radical>reason</radical> we have so much <kanji>oil</kanji> now. The tsunami moved a bunch of earth out of the way, so now it’s really easy to dig for oil. Thanks tsunami!

The <radical>commander</radical>'s <radical>alcohol</radical> is really just <kanji>soy sauce</kanji>. When he goes out to drink with his troops and they all get drunk together, he manages to have fun and stay sober by drinking down a tasty, non-alcoholic pint of soy sauce.

A <radical>tsunami</radical> goes through a little <radical>door</radical>, and plops down a <radical>big</radical> drop on your face. This tsunami is your tears inside your eye area. The door is your tear duct. The big drop is the <kanji>teardrop</kanji> coming down your eye.

Your <radical>car</radical> is <radical>dry</radical> because you kept it under the <kanji>eaves</kanji> of your house. 

This kanji has a second meaning too: <kanji>house counter</kanji>. Imagine counting all the houses on your block by the number of eaves you see keeping cars dry.
The <radical>mouth</radical> of the <radical>World</radical> <radical>Tree</radical>, all it does is <kanji>chat</kanji> and <kanji>talk</kanji>.

There's a <radical>slide</radical> with a <radical>drunkard</radical> <radical>above</radical> it, and they're making you feel <radical>small</radical>. And the worst part is that the drunkard is one of your <kanji>relatives</kanji>.
Try not to let your <radical>mouth</radical> get <radical>droopy</radical> — you'll dribble <kanji>saliva</kanji> everywhere.
